author: furriebunnie0730
content: normally on a project you would have like, a build script, test inputs, expected output, etc - do those kinds of things exist here?  like how do testers know that the env they are testing is valid?

author: sky.cactus
content: Each client has its own process, you'll have better luck poking around their individual repositories or talking to their teams.

author: sky.cactus
content: Nethermind, for example, is written in C# and you can test with `dotnet test <project_name>` run in the appropriate directory (and with the appropriate build tools).

author: furriebunnie0730
content: ya i get that - but im saying - dont the major players have to coordinate to make sure that besu doesnt screw geth, etc?  like all the clients have to work together in some test env before this goes live, no?

author: furriebunnie0730

author: sky.cactus
content: I *think* (don't quote me on this as I'm not intimately involved) what happens is that each client builds their thing separately along with their own integration test suites.  Then they join a test network together and they each run their own test suite against the shared test network.  If anyone desyncs from the network, everyone looks to see what the cause of the problem was (which client has a bug) and then that client fixes, rejoins the network, and everyone runs their test suite again.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially, each time builds their client mostly in isolation from the other teams, with the exception of connecting up to a shared test network.

author: sky.cactus
content: Some EIPs have tests attached to them, but 1559 does not.

author: furriebunnie0730

author: timbeiko
content: <@!323626686170136577> it would also be helpful to get a feel for _what_ you are trying to test: we've had various setups for different types of tests. Earlier you mentioned the 2718/1559 integration. If that's what you are after, in geth, then that code just isn't ready yet, like I mentioned previously.

author: timbeiko
content: If you just want to "run 1559", besu is probably best documented

author: timbeiko
content: Like Micah mentioned, the way we are testing implementations is having them on a single network and gathering metrics on the various nodes, but each client has its own approach to do this. We're also planning to do load testing on that network whenever all clients have synced to the chain head.

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
There's the suite of EIPs (3041 etc) for adding `baseFee` to the block RPCs, are there similar EIPs in the works for the RPC changes for transactions, for example changes to  `eth_getTransactionByHash` and `eth_getTransactionReceipt` etc for EIP-1559/2718/2930?  I see that quilt branch uses terms like `gasFee`, `inclusionFee` and `accessList` but it's not clear to me that besu for example is using the same JSON names for these fields.

edit: I see <#804019759934078987> has some life again, happy to move this conversation over there if more appropriate
